sn16.5:4.2: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.
sn16.5:4.3: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha,
sn16.5:4.4: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn16.5:4.6: “You’re old now, Kassapa. Those worn-out hempen rag robes must be a burden for you.
sn16.5:4.7: So Kassapa, you should wear clothes given by householders, accept invitations for the meal, and stay in my presence.”
sn16.5:5.1: “For a long time, sir, I’ve lived in the wilderness, eaten only alms-food, worn rag robes, and owned just three robes; and I’ve praised these things. I’ve been one of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and I’ve praised these things.”
sn16.5:6.1: “But seeing what benefit, Kassapa, have you long practiced these things?”
sn16.5:7.1: “Sir, seeing two benefits I have long practiced these things.
sn16.5:8.1: I see a happy life for myself in the present. And I have compassion for future generations, thinking:
sn16.5:8.2: ‘Hopefully those who come after might follow my example.’
sn16.5:8.3: For they may think: ‘It seems that the awakened disciples of the Buddha for a long time lived in the wilderness, ate only alms-food, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; and they praised these things. They were of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praised these things.’
sn16.5:8.12: They’ll practice accordingly, which will be for their lasting benefit and happiness.
sn16.5:9.1: Seeing these two benefits I have long practiced these things.”
sn16.5:10.2: You’re acting for the welfare and happiness of many people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
sn16.5:10.3: So Kassapa, wear worn-out hempen rag robes, walk for alms, and stay in the wilderness.”
